episodes.title: Is this a cult? Ex-Amish Answers Your Questions | Honesty Box
episodes.description:
In this episode of Honesty Box, we had the pleasure of speaking to Naomi Swartzentruber about life growing up in the world's strictest Amish community, the Swartzentruber Amish. For 17 years, Naomi lived a simple Amish life, free from technology and modern comforts. Naomi answers your brilliant questions: Why don't the Amish use technology? Can you have sex before marriage? And, are Amish people happier? 

Thank you to Naomi Swartzentruber for taking part in this episode of Honesty Box. 
Naomi's memoir is available here: https://www.amazon.co.uk/Amazing-Adventures-Amish-Stripper-ebook/dp/B0CC97HW27

episodes.title: Police Detective On Organ Harvesting, Sex Rings & Cults | Minutes With
episodes.description:
In this episode of Minutes With, we sat down with former London Metropolitan Police Officer Phil Brewer, to speak about his work tackling the crime of human trafficking and modern slavery. Phil explains how he worked to uncover a Maoist cult, organ harvesting plot and sex ring operation in London. Phil reflects on the hidden nature of this crime, telling us about one man who had been a domestic slave for 26 years and how the perpetrators were finally brought to justice.

Thank you to Phil Brewer for taking part in this episode of Minutes With. For more information about human trafficking and modern slavery please visit this website: https://www.unseenuk.org/about-modern-slavery/spot-the-signs/

episodes.title: How The Church Of Scientology Ruined My Life | Honesty Box
episodes.description:
In this episode of Honesty Box, we delve into the world of Scientology with Jon Atack, a former member turned authoritarian cult expert and author. Jon provides invaluable insights into his personal experiences within Scientology, shedding light on the hypnotic techniques used, the hierarchy, leadership and origins story of the organisation. He reveals details about celebrity involvement, and explores the daunting commitment of the Sea Organisation, where members sign a billion year pledge upon joining.

episodes.title: My Abusive Father Locked Me Inside For 30 Years | Minutes With | @LADbible
episodes.description:
In this week's episode of Minutes With, we sat down with Katy Morgan-Davies, born into a London cult. Known as the 'Communist Collective' and led by her father Aravindan Balakrishnan (AB), it operated as a cult of personality. Katy discusses being locked in the house for 30 years, the power dynamics of the group and the abuse she suffered at the hands of cult members. 

Thank you to Katy for taking part. You can buy her memoir, 'Caged Bird' on amazon - https://www.amazon.co.uk/Caged-Bird-Katy-Morgan-Davies/dp/059307968X.

episodes.title: Abuse I Went Through Inside A Cult | No Filter |@LADbible
episodes.description:
In this episode of No Filter we talked to Calvin Wayman, who was a part of The Work Of Jesus Christ church, which is closely associated with the FLDS cult and he grew up with 44 siblings (and 5 parents). 

His family practiced polygamy, and growing up in Utah, Calvin enjoyed having a large family but started to step out of the religion and the community in his 20s. Four years ago (in 2018), he made the decision to leave.

Thanks to Calvin for taking part!

episodes.title: I Grew Up In A Cult Without Realising | No Filter | @LADbible
episodes.description:
Faith Elizabeth Hunter, who goes by Liz, was raised in Texas in a family belonging to the Institute in Basic Life Principles (IBLP) – also known as ATI – an ultra-conservative Christian sect established in 1961.

As a child, Liz remembers that her family had no television, and weren’t allowed to watch films or TV or listen to any non-Christian music, cutting off their exposure to the outside world.

Liz told UNILAD that instead, her entire upbringing was centred around traditional ideas of a patriarchal Christian family, and that most of her education consisted of Bible study, and learning how to be a good wife.

Things eventually changed for Liz when she left her hometown to go to college. Her parents had expected that she would ultimately return home and educate her siblings, and eventually her own children, but after making new friends, and going to see a therapist she says she began to realise that something wasn’t right.
